facts.text: Suit for partition instituted by the appellant in the Court of the Civil Judge Senior Division, Bijapur.

anchor.surface_text: VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-This appeal arises out of a suit for partition instituted by the appellant in the Court of the Civil Judge Senior Division, Bijapur.

Siddopant and Krishnarao represented one branch of a Kulkarni family and were entitled for their share of the Watan lands,

issues.text: Whether the properties purchased by Siddopant and the houses constructed by him and Devji were self-acquisitions or acquired with the aid of joint family funds from the nucleus of ancestral Watan lands, and whether the burden of proof was correctly placed on the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: The first contention that has been urged on behalf of the appellant is that the finding of the Courts below that the properties purchased by Siddopant and the houses constructed by him and Devji were self-acquisitions, is erroneous, firstly because the burden was wrongly cast on the plaintiff of proving that they were made with the aid of joint family funds,

issues.text: Whether the judgments in prior maintenance suits tendered by the plaintiff were wrongly rejected as inadmissible evidence under the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: It was, next contended that certain documents which were tendered in evidence had been wrongly rejected by the Courts below, and that the finding of self-acquisition reached without reference to those documents should not be accepted. These documents are judgments in two suits for maintenance

issues.text: Whether the house sites in Schedule A without title deeds (S. Nos. 634, 635, 639, 640, 641, 642, 644, 645) are ancestral joint family properties based on presumption from long possession

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the Watan lands which are admittedly ancestral, and apart from the purchases made under Exhibits. D-36, D- 61 and D-64 and the houses which we have held to be self- acquisitions, there are certain plots mentioned in Schedule A in which the plaintiff claims a half share.

issues.text: Whether the doctrine of relation back in adoption applies to allow the adopted son to divest properties inherited by a collateral (Swamirao's C Schedule properties vested in Devji)

anchor.surface_text: The point for determination now is whether this doctrine of relation back can be applied when the claim made by the adopted son relates not to the estate of his adoptive father but of a collateral. The theory on which this doctrine is based is that there should be no hiatus in,

anchor.surface_text: It was finally contended that the defendants had blended C Schedule properties along with the admitted ancestral properties so as to impress them with the character of joint family properties. The burden of proving blending is heavily on the plaintiff.
